setup.question: How did Hoshick feel about war?
answers: He would rather watch than take part
He saw it as an unfortunate necessity

Text.text: The story follows a small colony on an alien planet who has run into some conflicts with a very large group of aliens, also on the planet. Retief, a diplomat for a space organization, is sent out to try and mediate the issue and find some sort of resolution. Retief is able to secure an audience with the leader of the alien race, caled flap-jacks, and their leader, Hoshick. Hoshick is immediately characterized as one of those, like, over-the-top British dudes who really lean into being "gentlemanly."

Hoshick identifies himself as a sportsman, and he views the war as basically this fun activity that his skirmisher groups get to screw around in, and he gets to watch. Hoshick never actually indicates that he feels like he needs the war, he just wants it around as a sport. He has a very lighthearted approach to the entire conflict, and when
. He clearly isn't regretful of the war, and doesn't think it's necessary.
I would like to see more conclusive evidence as to him watching and explicitly not taking part.
There isn't ev of Hoshick watching bc the war doesn't actually happen, Retief sets a wager w Hoshick, one on one combat, to prevent the war:
Hoshick identifies himself as a sportsman, not a warrior, and views the war as "
" Also I completely just didn't see this quote before, but here it is:
He says this after Hoshick proposes that the two fight it out to resolve the conflict.
That last quote is very conclusive.
Is the duel the same as the war? And if so, seemingly Hosjock does go to war in one to one combat...

answers.reason for outcome: A had a very conclusive quote to prove their answer.
I had a hunch, but i would have liked to ask more questions. But based on the ev and the fact that the debate had ended, I had to chose, and A was more compelling.
